docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the proposal for a settlement reached last Friday by tobacco industry representatives, a group of state attorneys general and plaintiffs' lawyers. The agreement is expected to alter the nation's legal, regulatory and public health landscape permanently. Among other changes, the proposed settlement would require cigarette companies to pay $368.5 billion over the next 25 years to compensate states for the costs of treating smoking-related illness, to finance nationwide anti- smoking programs and to underwrite health care for millions of uninsured children. The text was downloaded from the Web site at http://stic.neu.edu run by the State Tobacco Information Center, an information clearing house created to provide information for the public and attorneys general involved in the case. Preamble This legislation would mandate a total reformation and restructuring of how tobacco products are manufactured, marketed and distributed in this country. The nation can thereby see real and swift progress in preventing underage use of tobacco, addressing the adverse health effects of tobacco use and changing the corporate culture of the tobacco industry.

headline.main: Excerpts From Agreement Between States and Tobacco Industry

docs.abstract: Excerpts from proposal for settlement reached by tobacco industry representatives, group of state attorneys general and plaintiffs' lawyers (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: When the bell rings to signal a change of class at Parkway Middle School here, the principal, Willie Dudley, turns traffic cop as a mob of boisterous teen-agers pours out onto the 16-acre campus. His task is to get hundreds of students into their next classrooms within five minutes. Ten minutes later, he is still yelling: ''Let's go! Daniel! Don't make the girls late now, you're holding them up. Come on, you all. Come on, young lady. Jacob! Let's go! Come on, ladies, hustle up!''

headline.main: In Florida, the Young Are Gaining on the Old

docs.abstract: Florida, long identified with old people, is struggling with surge of young people; children 5 to 17 years of age now account for 2.2 million, or 16 percent, of state's population of 14 million; demographers project that from 1990 to 2000, number of school-age children in state will grow by 25 percent, while that of residents 65 and over will grow by 22 percent; Gov Lawton Chiles has formed commission to study problem of school overcrowding and plans to summon State Legislature to special session to deal with it; graph; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate voted today to increase Medicare premiums for affluent elderly people and to raise the age of eligibility by two years, to 67. Together, the proposals would make profound changes in Medicare, forcing elderly people to take more responsibility for their health care and their health insurance.

headline.main: SENATE BACKS RISE IN MEDICARE COSTS FOR WEALTHY AGED

docs.abstract: Senate votes to increase Medicare premiums for affluent elderly people and to raise age of eligibility by two years, to 67; proposals would make profound changes in Medicare, forcing elderly people to take more responsibility for their health care and their health insurance; fate of both proposals is in doubt; Pres Clinton wants Congress to take them out of bill; House version of legislation omits them; vote to charge higher premiums for higher-income elderly people is 70 to 30; vote to increase age of eligibility is 62 to 38; Senate, by vote of 60 to 40, decides to establish new charge of $5 a visit for home health care services under Medicare; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The half-dozen top lobbyists sipping cocktails in the dimly lighted library of the City Club suspended their talk of golf and dieting (without giving up red wine or red meat) to raise a glass to Thomas J. Donohue, head persuader for the trucking industry, who had just been named president of the United States Chamber of Commerce. ''He's the junkyard dog, the George C. Patton of the trade associations,'' said W. Henson Moore, a former member of Congress from Louisiana who is president of the American Forest and Paper Association. He meant it as a compliment.

headline.main: Master Persuader Will Run the Leading Business Lobby

docs.abstract: Profile of Thomas J Donohue, trucking industry chief lobbyist set to become United States Chamber of Commerce president; he promises to bring new edge to what is still nation's leading business lobby, interview; chamber has lost membership and influence in recent years under outgoing president, Richard L Lesher; tables; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: ENROLLING human beings as research subjects for pharmaceutical trials has always been controversial, particularly since the 1950's when the horrific consequences of the drug thalidomide in pregnant women became clear. Meant to combat nausea, the drug brought on major deformities, including missing arms and legs, in unborn children. Among the organizations around the country dealing with the conditions under which research may go forward is the Human Investigation Committee at the Yale University School of Medicine, whose chairman is Dr. Robert J. Levine, a professor of medicine.

headline.main: Drugs for Humans, Tested on Humans
headline.kicker: Connecticut Q&A: Dr. Robert J. Levine

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Robert J Levine, chmn of Human Investigation Committee of Yale School of Medicine; he comments on protocols for conducting clinical trials of drugs, and ethical issues involved in enrolling human beings as research subjects for pharmaceutical trials; thalidomide disaster recalled; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: DRESSED in a deep-green bodysuit and wraparound sunglasses, blond hair pulled up like a pineapple on her head, Ann Marie Murphy was not the least bit self-conscious about sitting at a bar with a hose up her nose. Ms. Murphy, a physical-fitness trainer, sometimes feels the need for a breath of fresh air, and so she stopped by a neighborhood bar between training sessions -- not for a quick nip but for a shot of lemon-and-lime-scented oxygen. ''You feel a feeling of not quite euphoria but almost an energy lift,'' she said, relaxing on a fashionable steel stool in front of a gently curved marble bar at the O2 Spa Bar in Toronto, the first walk-in air saloon in North America.

headline.main: Just When You Thought Air Was Free

docs.abstract: Oxygen has become marketable commodity as nutritional supplement and cosmetic aid, but concept of oxygen-as-elixir is seen with widespread skepticism in medical community; customers of successful O2 Spa Bar in Toronto, Canada, sit at bar with tubes up their noses, breathing in 99.9 percent pure oxygen passed through cups of flavored water, at a price of US$12 for 20 minutes; O2 Spa is negotiating leases to open three bars in New York City; photos (M)
